newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: U.N. Zaire envoy says Zaire foes agreed to meet.
newsitem.headline: U.N. Zaire envoy says Zaire foes agreed to meet.

text.p: The leaders of Zaire's warring factions have agreed in principle to meet for talks, the U.N.'s special envoy on Zaire announced on Thursday.

"The outcome we have today (is) the agreement in principle by the two parties to meet at the highest level ... to discuss transitional arrangements," U.N. envoy Mohamed Sahnoun told a news conference.
South African deputy foreign affairs minister Aziz Pahad told the news conference the talks would be without preconditions.
He said President Nelson Mandela had formally invited Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seko to visit South Africa for talks with rebel leader Laurent Kabila.
Sahnoun said the foes had agreed the ultimate goal of the talks should be elections for Zaire -- part of a joint declaration issued by the two sides after talks in South Africa earlier this month.
It was not clear when a summit might take place.
